senses.de: A huge change in something, like a government or way of doing things

Tips.title: Historical Events
Tips.description: Used when discussing historical events that resulted in significant changes.
Tips.example: Textbooks often feature chapters on the French Revolution.

Tips.title: Political Change
Tips.description: References dramatic political transformation, often involving conflict.
Tips.example: The revolution overthrew the old dictatorship.

Tips.title: Social Movements
Tips.description: Can describe major shifts in societal attitudes and behaviors.
Tips.example: The sexual revolution changed many traditional norms.

senses.de: One full cycle of something turning around in a circle
senses.ex: The Earth makes one revolution around the sun every year.

Tips.title: Scientific Context
Tips.description: Often found in scientific texts, explaining astronomical or mechanical motion.
Tips.example: Mercury completes a revolution around the sun very quickly.

Tips.title: Repeated Action
Tips.description: Implies a single, complete turn in a series of similar actions.
Tips.example: The motor completed 10,000 revolutions per minute.

senses.de: A new and better way of doing something
senses.ex: The digital revolution changed the way we use technology.

Tips.title: Technological Advancements
Tips.description: Speaks to groundbreaking changes in technology that alter daily life.
Tips.example: The smartphone sparked a revolution in communication.

Tips.title: Innovation Periods
Tips.description: Marks periods of rapid advancements in fields like science or industry.
Tips.example: The biotech revolution led to new medical treatments.

Coup.wordDefinition:
A coup is a sudden and often violent overthrow of a government by a small group of people, typically within the existing power structure or military.

A coup is applicable when a small group of people within the government or military seek to take over the existing power structure, while a revolution is applicable when large groups of people mobilize to bring about significant change.

Insubordinate.wordDefinition:
Insubordinate refers to someone who disobeys or refuses to follow orders given by a higher authority such as a boss, teacher or parent.

So, while insubordinate refers to someone not following an authority figure's instructions, revolution is a more sweeping change in a country or social group.

Insurrection.wordDefinition:
Insurrection refers to a violent uprising against an existing government or authority, often for the purpose of overthrowing it.

Insurrection involves violent actions aimed at overthrowing a specific government or authority, while revolution involves deep and sometimes peaceful changes to an entire society.

Insurrection is usually considered more extreme and dangerous, while revolution can be seen as a more gradual and sustainable path to change.

Mutiny.wordDefinition:
Mutiny refers to a rebellion or uprising against the authority of a particular group or organization, such as a military unit or a ship's crew.

So, in short, mutiny is an act of rebellion against a particular authority as a way of protesting against specific decisions or actions that affect a smaller group of people.

Overthrow.wordDefinition:
Overthrow means to forcefully remove a government or ruler from power.

Unlike overthrow, revolution seeks to build a better world by dismantling the current system from within. It is enacted through peaceful protests, civil disobedience, and the creation of new institutions that better govern the people.

To summarize, while an overthrow is a sudden, violent removal of a leader, a revolution is a transformative, albeit gradual, reimagining of a society.

Rebellion.wordDefinition:
Rebellion refers to an attempt by a group of people to overthrow or resist the authority that currently exists, while still maintaining the overall structure or system in place.

In simpler terms, rebellion is like fighting against the rules made by the authorities in a specific system, while revolution is more like changing the entire system itself.

Rebellion can happen within a system, while revolution changes the system as a whole.

Riot.wordDefinition:
A riot refers to a violent and disorderly disturbance in public order. It involves the use of force, destruction of property, and often results in injuries or deaths.

Riots are usually unplanned and are fueled by anger, frustration, and distrust towards the government or authority. For example, the Minneapolis riots in 2020 were a result of the killing of George Floyd by police officers.

A revolution is a peaceful and planned change for a better future while a riot is an unplanned and violent disturbance in public order.

Uprising.wordDefinition:
Uprising refers to a spontaneous or unplanned rebellion, often led by the people against the government or ruling power.

Think of it as a sudden, grassroots movement that gains momentum and often leads to violence. Examples of uprisings include the Arab Spring and the Rose Revolution in Georgia.

Both words involve a significant change in political power, but a revolution is planned and organized, while an uprising is spontaneous and often violent.

Revolutions typically result in systemic change over the long term, while uprisings often have short-term impacts and may result in a change of government, but not necessarily systemic change.

quotes.Text: It blows my mind when I actually consider that men are as human as I am. How can you possibly be as human and have all of the thoughts and feelings that I have and never be able to talk about it, ever? Guys are in desperate need of truth telling. They are in desperate need of a revolution.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Glennon Doyle Melton

quotes.Text: The brutalities of progress are called revolutions. When they are over we realize this: that the human race has been roughly handled, but that it has advanced.
quotes.Title: French Author
quotes.Name: Victor Hugo

quotes.Text: The revolution in deep nets has been very profound. It definitely surprised me, even though I was sitting right there.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Sergey Brin

quotes.Text: Revolutions demand enormous sacrifices and, at the same time, create a new need to change the world again.
quotes.Title: Swiss Author
quotes.Name: Friedrich Durrenmatt

quotes.Text: Remember that the revolution is what is important, and each one of us, alone, is worth nothing.
quotes.Title: Argentinian Revolutionary
quotes.Name: Che Guevara

quotes.Text: Promise yourself to live your life as a revolution and not just a process of evolution.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Anthony J. D'Angelo

quotes.Text: Those who make peaceful revolution impossible will make violent revolution inevitable.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: John F. Kennedy

quotes.Text: The wave of the Islamic revolution will soon reach the entire world.
quotes.Title: Iranian Statesman
quotes.Name: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad

quotes.Text: Your life continues in those who continue the revolution.
quotes.Title: Leader
quotes.Name: Samora Machel

quotes.Text: The only way to support a revolution is to make your own.
quotes.Title: American Activist
quotes.Name: Abbie Hoffman
